text:
Stubborn Crimea from Stavanger
CRIMES: Brutal spell killer in entertaining, but a little too long Crime novel.
07 Nov 2019, 11:37 by Tarald Aano



1 2 3 4 5 6


Lars Helle: When the storm never lies. 511 pages. Life publishers.


He does not make it easy for himself, Crimean author Lars Helle.
He doesn't make it easy for the reader either.
Prior to writing eight pages, he served no less than four different text and schedules: A Kind of Contemporary History (2012) in which a young woman shows up with detective / writer Kurt Stille (who thought she was dead a long time ago), a letter from her "mother", an excerpt from Stille's previous novel, and a leap almost 30 years back in time (1984).
Whew.
Four to five pages farther on, it appears another level of text; print of a police questioning carried out in 2013. Even further out in the book we also get big bullets from both 1994 and 2004. Overall, it gets a little too much, a little too far.
But hold on. After breaking through the cover of the entire book on the first pages, Helle steals her story pretty confidently. Essentially chronological, and with threads that link the various events and people together.


ğŸ“· Anders Minge

So it is about a woman everyone thought died as a baby, after a brutal murder of her babysitter. Twenty-two years later, new killings occur, and Kurt Stille tries to solve the mystery of the fictional island of SmalÃ¸y outside Stavanger. There lived a really colorful bunch; an extremely strict bishop, a fanatical Christian rocker, a fallen grand prix artist, a football player, a homophobic teacher, a deranged writer ... The person gallery may not always be as credible; 1984, but so be it.
This is not a social-realistic novel about crimes. "When the Storm Never Lays" is a slightly ironic who-did-it-crime with a rap jaw investigator in the narrator role. Kurt Stille has the same humor as Gunnar Holt (as Helle has written many books about in the past), and he lets the two (anti) heroes meet midway in this book - a small find to the delight of faithful readers.
New readers will also find a lot of entertainment in this book, at least those who will even go killer hunting between the perms and manage to hold the threads without it being vase.
Linguistically it works mostly, Helle is a good observer and loves ironic remarks. And this book also shows that he is the strongest supplier of Crimea from the Stavanger area of the time. But I get annoyed when he writes about "endless second", "endless seconds" and "endless moment". Then he is so far into the clichÃ©d country that the publisher should have stopped him.
